DOC.HEAD: General Assembly Calls for Global Ban on Driftnet Fishing
DOC.TEXT: The General Assembly on Friday unanimously called for an end to driftnet fishing in the South Pacific in 1991 and a global ban on use of the huge nets a year later. The resolution, adopted by consensus, denounces driftnet fishing as ``a highly indiscriminate and wasteful fishing method which is widely considered to threaten the effective conservation of living marine resources.'' Driftnets stretch up to 30 miles, scooping up all fish and other marine life. Dolphins, porpoises, sea birds and unwanted fish are killed along with the desired catch. Japan, Taiwan and South Korea have made extensive use of the nets in the Pacific Ocean to catch squid. More than 1,000 ships from many nations, including France, Spain and Italy, use the nets worldwide. The U.N. resolution recommends driftnet fishing be scaled down immediately in the South Pacific and ended there by July 1, 1991. It says a worldwide ban should go into effect on June 30, 1992. While not binding, the resolution will probably gain wide compliance, diplomats say. Japan, considered the biggest user of drift nets, has already announced it will stop. The ban, the resolution added, could be waived in a region ``should effective conservation and management measures be taken.'' Small-scale use of driftnets in coastal waters would be excluded. The resolution said such fishing is important to the economies of developing countries.
